repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
When opening a terminal it should drop you in insert mode so you can
start using it directly. While starting on insert mode is rare for
editors, it is the norm for terminal emulators. In other words, starting
the terminal in insert mode is likely more useful in the vast majority
of cases.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    group = nvim_terminal_augroup,
    command = 'startinsert',
```
and move this up to line 208, together with the other terminal autocommands.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -538,3 +538,10 @@ do
     vim.o.grepformat = '%f:%l:%c:%m'
   end
 end
+
+do
+  -- terminal
+  vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd({ 'TermOpen' }, {
+    command = 'startinsert',

@@ -538,3 +538,10 @@ do
     vim.o.grepformat = '%f:%l:%c:%m'
   end
 end
+
+do
+  -- terminal
+  vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd({ 'TermOpen' }, {
+    command = 'startinsert',

comment_regular_data.body: We've talked about this before and there was a reason we didn't do this. Let me see if I can find the discussion.

This was already discussed and rejected. Search the issues/PRs. 

If there is a problem with the sample snippet that provides a way to opt-into this via an autocmd, then that should be fixed. 

Why is :terminal any different than a normal buffer? Both have insert-mode, but both default to normal-mode. There are lots of use-cases where one may want to navigate a :terminal buffer, why is it assumed that one wants to start typing stuff?

>Why is :terminal any different than a normal buffer? Both have insert-mode, but both default to normal-mode. There are lots of use-cases where one may want to navigate a :terminal buffer, why is it assumed that one wants to start typing stuff?

We already have some special sauce for "shell terminals" (i.e. a buffer started with `:terminal` with no arguments) to close them automatically if they exit without an error. Automatically starting insert mode in that case seems harmless and mostly useful?

> We already have some special sauce for "shell terminals" (i.e. a buffer started with `:terminal` with no arguments) to close them automatically if they exit without an error.

That case is near-zero cost. That's different than this case, which is closer to 50/50.

Why is it "harmless" to start :terminal in insert-mode, but not for normal buffers?

Because a fresh `:terminal` is virtually guaranteed to have no useful content to interact with other than by typing. And differently from a normal buffer, insert mode puts you at the prompt **which normal mode doesn't start at**. So the "most useful starting state" is massively skewed, unlike a normal buffer.

>Why is it "harmless" to start :terminal in insert-mode, but not for normal buffers?

Only when `:terminal` is a shell. It's harmless because when a shell is started, there is nothing to do in normal mode. There is only a prompt. There is nothing for the user to do except press `i` to enter insert mode anyway.

In a normal buffer, text can be edited/moved/modified/scrolled/etc. in Normal mode. The "default action" is not to add new text. In a (newly opened) shell terminal, that is not only the default action, but the _only_ action available.
You _could_ paste text, but even then exiting insert mode would be just as quick -- if not quicker, if you have right-side prompts -- to position the cursor to where you need to paste it.

> Only when `:terminal` is a shell

If we restrict this to that case, then I guess I don't have a strong objection. 

But the same argument could be made for empty, normal buffers. Which is why I don't like this: it's inconsistent. Hitting "i" seems like a small price to pay for predictability. And anyone who disagrees can add a snippet to their config.

> This was already discussed and rejected. Search the issues/PRs.

I found two issues about this: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/2815 and https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/8816.

I'm reading through them now to see if something legible was written.

> And anyone who disagrees can add a snippet to their config.

This is always the case. The point of default changes is that defaults matter, not whether something is easy or possible.

In any case, I'll read through the comments and experiment to get a better understand of people's usecases to see if this behavior is too breaking/useful. I didn't anticipate this being a controversial topic, or something that was extensively discussed before.

>>And anyone who disagrees can add a snippet to their config.
>
>This is always the case. The point of default changes is that defaults matter, not whether something is easy or possible.

I will also point out that the exact same is true (adding a snippet to their config) for anyone who disagrees with the default ðŸ™‚

> But the same argument could be made for empty, normal buffers.

And we just pointed out how the argument is different and does _not_ apply to empty, normal buffers.

> And we just pointed out how the argument is different and does _not_ apply to empty, normal buffers.

ctrl-f "empty" finds nothing. Which comment explains why empty buffers should start in normal-mode, but "shell terminal" should start in insert-mode?

> I will also point out that the exact same is true (adding a snippet to their config) for anyone who disagrees with the default ðŸ™‚

As usual, what matters is if there is strong reasoning one way or other. If it's 50/50, then the tie-breaker is consistency/tradition.

> As usual, what matters is if there is strong reasoning one way or other. If it's 50/50, then the tie-breaker is consistency/tradition.

Depends on how much value one places in this of course, but one aspect of this is that this is more consistent and is more in tradition with how vim behaves. I'm aware neovim was first to launch a terminal, but since neovim is nonetheless a fork of vim I'd still say it counts for something.
Anyway, I admit defeat, seems this wasn't as popular as I thought it would be. Thanks for everyone's input.
If you want to take on something less controversial, you can spearhead https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24914.

title: feat(defaults)!: automatically start terminal in insert mode
